item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israel’s Military Widens Evacuation Orders in Southern Gaza
item.description: A military spokesman said on Sunday that Israel “continues to expand its ground operation” against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip fled their homes on Saturday.

item.title: Ukrainian Refugees in Germany Weigh Tough Choice: Stay or Go Home
item.description: As refugees, they were welcomed with safety, services and jobs. As the war grinds on, giving that up is not a simple decision.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: The decommissioned Tegel airport in Berlin is a first stop for many Ukrainians arriving in Germany. About 3,000 are housed in large white halls close to a former runway.

item.title: Maduro’s Vote to Annex Territory From Guyana Is Seen as a Diversion
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro says an oil-rich part of Guyana belongs to Venezuela. Voters agreed on Sunday, but turnout appeared to be low.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: A mural of the Venezuelan map, with the Guyanese territory of Essequibo included, last week in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Israeli Mothers Knew Their Sons Would Serve. But They Didn’t Expect War.
item.description: Many mothers are grappling with anxiety as their sons head off to fight in Gaza. “It felt like my children were being taken away, one by one, until no one was left,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mothers of Israeli soldiers praying and making challah together in Jerusalem last month.

item.title: Explosion at Catholic Mass in Philippines Kills 4 and Injures Dozens
item.description: The blast, which was claimed by the Islamic State, occurred in a restive area in the south that was the site of a devastating battle with an ISIS affiliate six years ago.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Lanao del Sur Provincial Government/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Police investigators on Sunday at the site of an explosion at Mindanao State University in the south Philippine city of Marawi.

item.title: Paris Knife Attack Leaves One Dead and Others Injured
item.description: The authorities said the suspect had serious psychiatric disorders and told the police he was upset over the deaths of Muslims around the world, including in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Near the Bir-Hakeim Bridge in Paris after a man armed with a knife and a hammer attacked people, killing a German tourist.

item.title: Tracing the Deep Roots of Ireland’s Support for Palestinians
item.description: In a country with its own history of a seemingly intractable conflict, the majority of people in Ireland are sympathetic to Palestinian civilians, while also condemning the Hamas attacks of Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A pro-Palestinian mural in Dublin last month. Ireland’s support for Palestinian civilians is rooted in what many see as a shared history of colonialism.

item.title: Israeli Intelligence Errors Over Hamas Attack Plan Prompt Scrutiny, but Little Backlash
item.description: The Israeli media and The New York Times published damaging revelations suggesting that senior officers had ignored or dismissed intelligence reports about the likelihood of a major Hamas attack.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house at a kibbutz in southern Israel that was overrun by Hamas fighters on Oct. 7.

item.title: Japan to Limit Unusual Baby Names
item.description: As such names have increased, so has media attention to cases of people unhappy with them. But critics say new rules may infringe on the right to be creative.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Shina Peng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuuki Matsumoto, formerly Yuni, at his residence in Yokohama, Japan.

item.title: After Watching 10 Migrants Die at Sea, He Now Pleads: ‘Stay’
item.description: Witness to a tragedy on a boat to Spain, Moustapha Diouf has made it his mission to persuade young people not to emigrate from Senegal, but even he concedes that it’s getting harder to make his case.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Carmen Abd Ali
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Expels Ex-Chile Army Officer to Face Charges in Killing of Víctor Jara
item.description: Pedro Barrientos, 74, was charged in the kidnapping, torture and killing of the popular folk singer Víctor Jara days after the 1973 military coup that deposed President Salvador Allende.
item.dc:creator: Pascale Bonnefoy
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Pedro Barrientos, center, was deported from the United States to Chile on Friday, after being charged with the torture and killing of the folk singer Víctor Jara in 1973.

item.title: Crossing the Dnipro: What a Ukrainian Military Operation Might Mean
item.description: Ukrainian troops have taken positions on the east bank of the Dnipro River, posing a threat to Russia’s dominance of the region. Here is a look at the battlefield and the strategic implications.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on the shores of the Dnipro River at the front line near Kherson in October.

item.title: He Won Election to Canada’s Parliament. Did China Help?
item.description: A Canadian rapporteur said there was “well-grounded suspicion” that Han Dong, a member of Parliament from Toronto, may have benefited from support from the Chinese Consulate.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Han Dong, speaking in February and elected to Canada’s Parliament in 2019 as a member of the Liberal Party, is the subject of an investigation into Chinese election interference.

item.title: Israelis Are Angry at Netanyahu, but Replacing Him Is Difficult
item.description: Many hold Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu responsible for his government’s failure to prevent the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas. His legacy could be determined by his actions in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: A woman writes on a poster in Tel Aviv depicting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and pictures of hostages seized by Hamas on Oct. 7.

item.title: Volcanic Eruption Kills at Least 11 Hikers in Indonesia
item.description: Dozens of climbers were on Mount Marapi in Sumatra when it began spewing ash, the authorities said. Twelve were still missing.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Rin Hindryati
item.media:description: A farmer in West Sumatra Province in Indonesia on Monday, with Mount Marapi in the distance.

item.title: Kiwi Eggs Hatch in the Wild Near New Zealand’s Capital
item.description: The national bird, the kiwi, has hatched eggs in the wild in the Wellington area for the first time in living memory, thanks to a multiyear conservation effort.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie

item.title: The Wild Card in Taiwan’s Election: Frustrated Young Voters
item.description: An important bloc for the governing party, the island’s youth are focusing on bread-and-butter issues and have helped propel the rise of an insurgent party.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zhongshan District in Taipei, Taiwan. Many voters on the island, especially those in their 20s and 30s, say they are weary of geopolitics and yearn for a campaign more focused on their needs at home.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: An evacuation order in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Khan Younis in southern Gaza fleeing their homes.

item.title: Israel Orders Southern Gaza Residents to Evacuate
item.description: As its ground forces prepared to move in the south of Gaza, residents there were told to leave their homes, spreading fear and confusion.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Iyad Abuheweila and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike left a crater on Sunday in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Paris Attack Suspect Pledged Allegiance to Islamic State
item.description: The man, identified as Armand Rajabpour-Miyandoab, was known to French intelligence services for Islamist extremism and psychiatric disorders.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: French forensic policemen in Paris early Sunday following a knife attack.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Big State Victories for Modi
item.description: Plus Israel’s campaign in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Shivraj Singh Chouhan, the chief minister of Madhya Pradesh and a B.J.P. member, greeted supporters yesterday.

item.title: U.S. Navy Destroyer Is Attacked in the Red Sea, Pentagon Says
item.description: A Pentagon official said the U.S.S. Carney shot down the drones as several commercial ships nearby came under fire on Sunday, in attacks that U.S. Central Command said came from Iran-backed Yemeni Houthis.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The destroyer Carney near the Suez Canal in October, the same month it shot down drones and cruise missiles in the Red Sea.

item.title: U.S. Is Pressing Israel and Hamas to Resume Negotiations, Kirby Says
item.description: John Kirby said that Hamas was to blame for the breakdown in the negotiations, and that Israel was heeding U.S. advice on limiting civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Photos of those who are believed to remain captive in Gaza on a wall in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: With Big State Victories, Modi Expands His Dominance in India
item.description: Results of voting for the governments of four Indian states showed gains for Mr. Modi’s ruling party, putting him in a strong position ahead of general elections in the spring.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Shivraj Singh Chouhan, the chief minister of the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh and a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party, is greeted by supporters in Bhopal, India, on Sunday.

item.title: Munich Airport Resumes Operations After Major Snowfall
item.description: Heavy snow in Southern Germany on Saturday prompted authorities to shut the airport and rail station. Service at both remained limited on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: Munich’s closed airport after heavy snowfall hit Bavaria on Saturday.

item.title: Freed Israeli Hostages Give Tel Aviv Protesters Hope for Those in Captivity
item.description: Hostages who were recently released thanked demonstrators for continuing to pressure their government.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:description: Yelena Trupanob, right, and her mother, Irena Tati, who were recently released from captivity in Gaza, appearing at a rally in Tel Aviv on Saturday. Ms. Trupanob’s son, Sasha, is still being held hostage in Gaza.

item.title: Harris Says U.S. Strongly Opposes ‘Forced Relocation of Palestinians From Gaza’
item.description: The vice president’s statement came after a daylong meeting with Arab leaders in Dubai, where she was attending the U.N. climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s trip had been announced as climate-related, but she spent far more time talking with Arab leaders about the Israel-Hamas war.

item.title: 7.6-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Philippines but Tsunami Warnings Are Lifted
item.description: The authorities in Japan and the Philippines lifted tsunami warnings in coastal regions after ordering evacuations. Power failures near the epicenter were reported.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez

item.title: Israel Orders Evacuations Amid ‘Intense’ Attacks on Southern Gaza
item.description: Beleaguered Gazans, having fled the territory’s north, emerged from a night of bombardment wondering where to go next for safety.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians fled their homes in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip on Friday.

item.title: Why Don’t We Dance More?
item.description: Dancing offers an opportunity to use our bodies for something beyond mere practicality.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada Fast-Tracks 10.4 Billion Dollar Military Purchase
item.description: To avoid a seemingly endless process, the government takes some political heat.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Navy Poseidon planes at a base in Japan.

item.title: At COP28, More Than 20 Nations Pledge to Triple Nuclear Capacity
item.description: The group, including Britain, France and the United States, said the agreement was critical to meeting nations’ climate commitments.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at the United Nations climate summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Saturday. He said nuclear power was an “indispensable solution” in efforts to curb climate change.

item.title: Biden Administration Unleashes Powerful Regulatory Tool Aimed at Climate
item.description: Its new estimate of the economic impact of climate change could create the legal justification for aggressive new regulations.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Tucked in its new rules to curb methane emissions, the E.P.A. set a new social cost for carbon, a number almost four times its previous amount: $190 a ton.

item.title: Southern Gaza girds for the war’s next phase.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ben Hubbard and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning relatives in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Friday.

item.title: Cindy McCain, Head of World Food Program, Faces Staff Revolt Over Gaza Conflict
item.description: Staff members accused Ms. McCain, the W.F.P.’s leader, of not leveraging her position to speak out against the suffering of Palestinian civilians, and some have called for her removal.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Julien De Rosa
item.media:description: Cindy McCain, the director of the United Nation’s World Food Program, was appointed to her role earlier this year.

item.title: A protester self-immolates outside the Israeli Consulate in Atlanta.
item.description: A security guard tried to intervene but was unsuccessful, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Colbi Edmonds
item.media:credit: Jason Getz/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency personnel outside the Israeli consulate in Atlanta on Friday.

item.title: Henri Lopes, 86, Who Straddled Literature and Politics in Africa, Dies
item.description: His lauded fiction satirized abuses of power in the continent, but as a high official for the Republic of Congo, he benefited from a much-criticized government.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: With the End of the Cease-Fire, Concern Grows Over the Oldest Israeli Hostages Left Behind
item.description: Going without medicines, proper nutrition and other necessities leave many especially vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman
item.media:description: Ditza Heiman, 84, on Tuesday in an ambulance at the Sheba Medical Center after arriving on an Israeli army helicopter. She was part of a group of hostages released this week.

item.title: Freed Palestinians Were Mostly Young and Not Convicted of Crimes
item.description: Israel has released a total of 240 Palestinian prisoners and detainees during a weeklong pause in hostilities.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao, Karen Zraick, Anushka Patil and Gaya Gupta
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Israel Resumes Offensive in Gaza Strip After Truce With Hamas Ends
item.description: Talks on extending a weeklong cease-fire broke down, with each side blaming the other. The truce had included the release of hostages held in Gaza for people in Israeli prisons.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ben Hubbard and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourned relatives on Friday at a funeral in Khan Younis, in Gaza’s south.

item.title: At P.S.G., a Coach’s Vision Collides With a Star’s Power
item.description: The system may be the center of the modern soccer universe, but stars like Kylian Mbappé exert a gravity of their own.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Kylian Mbappé, now P.S.G.’s unquestioned king.

item.title: Some Freed Hostages Are Now Learning of Loved Ones’ Deaths
item.description: More than any of them are now learning for the first time that their relatives were killed on Oct. 7 or are still being held hostage.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams, Katherine Rosman, Emma Bubola and Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Hostages and Missing Families Forum, via Associated Press

item.title: Blinken Blames Hamas for Breaking Truce With Israel
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state said he also believed Israel was taking steps in this next phase of war to protect civilian lives in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken before departing from Al Maktoum International Airport in Dubai on Friday.

item.title: Alleged Plot to Kill Sikh Separatist Highlights Thorn in India’s Side
item.description: The charges are rooted in a decades-old dispute over the demand by some Sikhs for a sovereign state known as Khalistan carved out of northern India.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Members of the Sikh community protesting against Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in Washington in 2020.

item.title: Israel’s Next Aim Is Southern Gaza. U.S. Urges Restraint.
item.description: American officials are making clear to Israel that it cannot pursue a campaign in the south that would have the same devastating consequences as in the north.
item.dc:creator: Yara Bayoumy and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City last month.

item.title: Thief in Australia Steals Truck With 10,000 Krispy Kreme Doughnuts
item.description: A woman thought she was stealing a van. She got thousands of doughnuts as well.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Krispy Kreme doughnuts.

item.title: Surging U.S. Oil Production Brings Down Prices and Raises Climate Fears
item.description: American oil production is hitting record levels, delivering economic and foreign policy benefits but putting environmental goals further out of reach.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. oil producers are cranking out a record 13.2 million barrels a day, more than Russia and Saudi Arabia.

item.title: The truce broke down over the details of further hostage and prisoner exchanges, Israeli officials say.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: Smoke rising from Gaza while Israeli soldiers stand near the border with Gaza, in Israel, on Friday.

item.title: Russia Extends Detention of U.S. Journalist Alsu Kurmasheva
item.description: Alsu Kurmasheva, an editor who also holds Russian citizenship, was arrested in October on charges of failing to register as a foreign agent.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Alsu Kurmasheva, center, an editor at Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, at a court hearing in Kazan, Russia, on Friday. Her detention was extended to Feb. 5.

item.title: Israel had a blueprint for the Oct. 7 attacks a year ago. Officials dismissed it.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Hamas-led gunmen seized an Israeli military vehicle after infiltrating areas of southern Israel during the Oct. 7 attacks. A blueprint for similar attacks was circulating among Israeli leaders long before Hamas struck.

item.title: Dozens of Unclaimed Corpses Show That an Indian Conflict Continues
item.description: The government has tried to shift the focus. That’s harder with morgues still full of bodies six months after the start of ethnic violence in Manipur.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of ethnic clashes in Manipur in July. Minority Kukis have accused majority Meiteis of ethnic cleansing.

item.title: A Russian Village Buries a Soldier, and Tries to Make Sense of the War
item.description: In Russia, the pain and loss of the war in Ukraine are felt most profoundly in small villages, where a soldier’s burial produces not just grief but a yearning to find meaning in his death.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral for Garipul S. Kadyrov, a Russian soldier who was killed while fighting in Ukraine, in the village of Ovsyanka, Russia, this month.

item.title: A Back Door to Taylor Swift’s Australia Tickets? Not if You’re in Australia.
item.description: An online reseller has skirted the country’s restrictions on ticket sales, allowing Swifties elsewhere to buy admission to the star’s Eras Tour.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fans during Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour in Buenos Aires in November.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A leaked document revealing details of Hamas’s Oct. 7 plot.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman running to a shelter in her home in Ashkelon, Israel, on Oct. 7.

item.title: Talks were continuing in hopes of reviving the truce.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Victoria Kim, Michael Crowley and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Reacting after an Israeli airstrike in the southern Gaza Strip on Friday.

item.title: Exactly How Much Life is on Earth?
item.description: According to a new study, living cells outnumber stars in the universe, highlighting the deep, underrated link between geophysics and biology.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Artem Povarov, Mike Rosecope/Alamy; NASA; ESA/Euclid Consortium
item.media:description: Researchers calculated that Earth has more living cells — a million trillion trillion, or a 1 followed by 30 zeros — than grains of sand.

item.title: Return to Haiti of a Coup Leader Raises Concerns of More Turmoil
item.description: Guy Philippe, who helped lead the coup that ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in 2004, is back in the politically unstable country after serving time in a U.S. prison.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Guy Philippe, a leader of the 2004 coup in Haiti, is taken off a bus at Haiti’s National Police station, in Port-au-Prince, after he was deported from the United States on Thursday.

item.title: Blinken Urges Israel to Reduce Civilian Deaths as More Hostages Are Freed
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Israeli officials and a Palestinian leader on Thursday to seek improved conditions for Gaza’s civilians and to try to exert influence over Israel’s expected military offensive.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant in Tel Aviv on Thursday.

item.title: Biden’s Bond With Modi, India’s Leader, Is Tested by Alleged Plot
item.description: The charges illustrate how complicated it can be for American presidents to balance their relationships with deeply imperfect allies.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Julian E. Barnes and Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India during a state dinner at the White House in June. Officials said they had no information that Mr. Modi was aware of the alleged plot.
